summary:
Peter: MJ we’ve been dating for a couple years now and I’ve been meaning to ask you this question for a while
MJ: omg Peter...
body:
Peter: MJ we’ve been dating for a couple years now and I’ve been meaning to ask you this question for a while

MJ: omg Peter I

Peter: spare coochie ma’am?

tags: and everyone else who is a bit on the stabby side
summary: marvel AU where Spider-Man has a habit of finding spooky and/or terrifying murder-y anti-heroes whom ae doing their best to not...
body:
marvel AU where Spider-Man has a habit of finding spooky and/or terrifying murder-y anti-heroes whom ae doing their best to not be stabby around him

 Venom is like Spider-Man’s weird uncle, Ghost Rider and Blade ran into him on completely unrelated occasions, Wolverine is like his grumpy dad, Jessica Jones is that one aunt he tells his secrets and has to beg not to drop a truck on school bullies, and so forth

and he is completely unaware that they have 1. literally eaten people (okay that’s pretty much just Venom), 2. killed people so often they don’t even really notice it or care, 3. see the world in dark and gloomy terms where violence is the only thing they think they can offer it, and so on but

he thinks they’re good people.

he believes that they are heroes, way better than him, and he believes in them so much that they feel ashamed when they realize how sincere he is and so whenever he’s around, they act like the heroes he is convinced they are

and over time, it stops being an act

Spider-Man is such a hero, he convinces other people that they are too, they can’t possibly disappoint him

blog.name: domesticateddarkling
blog.title: Domesticated Darkling
blog.description: A Hausfrau By Any Other Name...

summary: I Love You Bill, but Let’s Get Real...
title: I Love You Bill, but Let’s Get Real...
body:
It’s probably one of the few times me and my beloved fiancee have disagreed on something.  Especially when it comes to inflammatory comments made by Bill Maher, who is an equal-opportunity rabble-rouser.  Controversy is his business, and Mr. Maher courts it whenever he can.  I can’t sit there and say that I haven’t been entertained, because I have -  and in some cases, I do agree with some of the statements that he’s made.  

Again, we find Bill at the wrong end of the proverbial stick, when he made a jab at the comic-loving community of ultra-nerds who put Stan Lee on a pedestal and refer to Saint Stan.  Heck, I was raised by a man who adores comic-books and plays video games on a near-daily basis (I’m looking at you Castlevania).  My beloved fiancee is also a comic book and video game nerd, and it’s one of the main things that I love about him - it’s an activity we can both enjoy.  

For the three of us - and others like us - it’s a source of entertainment and escapism.  But does that make us ignorant or uneducated?  No!  

Escapism is not always a beneficial way to pass the time.  Sometimes the best ‘entertainment’ enriches your mind - and your heart - and means meaning and value to one’s life.  Knowledge really is power, and those that are the real heroes are the ones that pass down that torch for others, so they too can find their way out of the dark.  But the passage of knowledge and ideas doesn’t have to be stodgy and dry.  

As a matter of fact, it can make its appearance through several escapist mediums, especially comic books.  Through comics, Stan Lee was able to build an empire, and from that lofty thrown was able to disseminate little nuggets of knowledge that benefit the whole of humanity: such as equality, kindness, and kinship.  And that “heroes” come from unexpected places. And, in a way, Stan Lee was a real-life hero to many children across the globe as he gave us characters that we could emulate, and look up to - examples of what a human being should be.  (Perhaps if you head read Stan’s Soapbox, you would be well-versed on how forward-thinking Stan was.)  

The message that Stan sent out is ageless.  It applies to everyone, young and old.  

I wonder if Bill had ever listened to Stan’s message, given the rather vile tone of the blog post.  Perhaps he hadn’t, as he was ready to place part of the blame on Stan’s comic-loving sycophants.  Granted, there may be some Republicans in the midst of Stan’s devoted followers, but a majority of them are just as progressive as Stan himself was, therefore most of them rightfully find the president-elect rather repugnant - because he stands for everything that they don’t.  

Trump’s rise to power came from those on the far-right.  The same Conservatives that go door-to-door handing out pamphlets, picketing in front of Planned Parenthood, and leaving those laughable Chick Tracks in the public bathroom.  Those are the people who can’t can’t stand people like Stan, or anything regarding freedom of expression.  In my eyes - and others - these are people hell-bent on sending us back into the Dark Ages, demolish our Democratic Republic and establishing a theocracy - because of deeply held dogmatic ideas. 

There are those who label themselves as part of the “Alt-Right,” who have been emboldened by Trump’s rhetoric, and have become more public about their bigotry.  A perfect example of this is the demonstrations in Charlottesville.  Not only did several people walk away injured, someone died as the result of the hate being demonstrated that day.  

In summary, if Bill Maher would swallow his pride for a minute, maybe he would see a similarity between himself, Mr. Lee, and those that look up to him.  He would realize that they despised the very thing that Trump represents.  

Just because I’ve been a fan doesn’t mean I can’t completely dismiss his actions as of late - and I will try my best not to do so.  If someone would bother to read to between the lines, I think they would understand what he’s getting at.  There’s a massive wave of anti-intellectualism crashing through the country at the moment, and even though we have more access to information in the past, more people are more complacent to just “not know.” This heavily applies to those who are in the far-right Evangelical and the Alt-Right movements.  Not only are both groups incredibly hostile to facts; they’ll happily skew them.  

And as much as I hate to say it right now, Bill Maher has been rather vocal about the atrocities committed by both groups - as he’s bold enough to call them out on their bullshit.  And he does it with finesse and humor that I personally admire.  What I loved about his show, Politically Correct, as that he had people from both sides of the fence, sitting down together in one room, having a dialogue.  Again, it was the progressive attitude of the show - and the host - that drew me in.  Who else in entertainment history could get Marilyn Manson and Florence Henderson in the same room together?  

My personal message to Bill?  Swallow your pride, realize your similarities between you and the comic nerds and apologize.
body_abstract: It’s probably one of the few times me and my beloved fiancee have disagreed on something.  Especially when it comes to inflammatory comments made by Bill Maher, who is an equal-opportunity rabble-rouser.  Controversy is his business, and Mr. Maher courts it whenever he can.  I can’t sit there and say that I haven’t been entertained, because I have -  and in some cases, I do agree with some of the statements that he’s made.

title: Thanksgiving Surprise / Teaser
body:
Hey everyone!

I just wanted to let you guys in on a little surprise I’ve been working on for this Thanksgiving. It’s been a hell of a year but I can honestly say I have a lot to be thankful for - you guys being one of those things! I just wanna say thank you for all the nice comments and interactions I’ve had with you guys. I have so much fun writing these stories and I’m glad our little community is so close ♡

Here’s a little teaser for what’s to come (sometime) tomorrow.
Have a Happy Thanksgiving everyone ♡

blog.name: comicscanbestupid
blog.title: Comics Can Be Stupid
blog.description:
Let's get one thing straight. I love comics. LOVE 'EM. 

That being said...they can be prettystupid at times. So, here's a collection of the odd, crazy, goofy, and flat out bizarre scenarios that have made it into some of our favorite comics.

summary: It must be hell to work in this environment.
body: It must be hell to work in this environment.

reblog.comment: It must be hell to work in this environment.

title: Playstation 101
body:
PlayStation struts into Black Friday boasting the most systems sold in this console generation. Yet, (perhaps therefore) their offering for Black Friday is a bit shallow. Good deals are still out there but you will find them in far fewer varieties than Xbox. To start things off, literally every big box and electronics store is going to have the Marvel’s Spider-Man Slim 1TB PS4 for $199.99. GameStop, Walmart, Best Buy, and Target all have the bundle and it is easily Sony’s best offering this year. Both Walmart and GameStop have a PSVR Bundle that includes Astro Bot, a charming VR platformer that is impressing critics across the board right now, all for a chill $199. For a VR headset bundle this is really nothing to shake a stick at. I have to emphasize though, these bundles DO NOT include the PS4. You must purchase that separately. Gamestop also has a PSVR bundle that includes both the acclaimed Moss, and perhaps the most fun shooter I have ever played SUPERHOT. That bundle weighs in at $249. If you are looking to grab a new controller you can find the Dualshock 4 nearly every where for $39.99.

If you were to ask me, your best deals can be found at:

Anywhere you can find the $199 Spider-Man Bundle
Anywhere you can find a controller
If you are looking to immerse yourself, Walmart and GameStop for PSVR

BLACK FRIDAY ADS:

Walmart
Best Buy
Target
Microsoft Store
GameStop

@LubWub

title: Comparing Cinematic Spidey-Bois
body:
Spoiler Alert: absolutely none of them follow the comics correctly so as if it even matters that much. But yeah otherwise, don’t worry about me spoiling any of the Spider-Man movies. I’ll keep it pretty simple and sum up every story line as well as provide my personal input.

So to start, we have obviously had different actors play Spider-Man for three different movies (as well as their respective continued movies). 

We got Tobey Maguire, who was Spider-Man for the 2002-2007 trilogy.

Andrew Garfield, who played Spider-Man for The Amazing Spider-Man which only got two movies between 2012-2014.

And the most recent kiddo who appeared in Civil War back in… what 2016? And still continues to today obviously, with Far From Home coming soon—Tom Holland.

I’ll go chronologically and start with Tobey Maguire.

Meet Peter Parker, the nerdy guy in high school who aspires to be a photographer and is mainly involved in science-related subjects. Bullied constantly by most of his peers throughout high school. He is best friends with Harry Osborne, while he has a shared crush on the hot red-haired girl next door named Mary Jane Watson. Things go wrong on a field trip, and he gets bitten by a spider that eventually turned him in Spider-Man literally overnight. Boom. Villains, fighting for the girl he loves, whatever. 

If I am to be perfectly honest, I have to say that Tobey Maguire’s representation of Spider-Man is the most true to the comics out of the three. Without a doubt in my mind whatsoever. There are striking inaccuracies, yet it at least includes the same concepts and characters. Stays really consistent.

I grew up with the trilogy—the movies were the reason why I became so invested into reading comics and watching other superhero movies. He of course became my favorite character, and I’ll admit that I’m biased by saying that Maguire’s Spider-Man is elite.

*bReAtH iN*

young male homosapien possessing XY chromosomes that also has external male genitalia.

I really wish I didn’t have to include this guy, but whatever. Some people like him. esketit.

Meet Peter Parker. It is clearly established early on in the film that his parents left, and all he has left is his Aunt May and Uncle Ben. Again, the bullied kid in high school that has a crush on the hot, intelligent girl named Gwen Stacy. Fucking edgy if you ask me, but he gets bitten by a spider again that progressively gives him his powers, and the rest is history. Amazing. Crime-fighting.

……. yes. 

I don’t like Garfield’s representation of Peter Parker because he was…something else. This one was more of an edgelord than a nerd that was invested in science and photography (as far as I can remember), so I dock the points there. I’ll give ‘im credit for having to build his own web slingers and produce his own web with chemicals because that is how the core spider-verse comics portray it—web doesn’t come out naturally.

Tom Holland is a little better although his overarching plotline is far from the core spider-verse comics, being intertwined with the Avengers and such. He gets credit for being a relatable, dumb kid like most of us. 

Meet Peter Parker. Clearly an awkward teenage boy who was suddenly granted these amazing powers that he has no idea what he is doing with. He has fortunately decided to use them for good is the important part, and he really tries his best to be independent like he feels he is expected to be. Bullied, nerdy high school student with his best buddy Ned and a crush on the hot, intelligent Senior girl. Good kid. His Aunt May gets hit on a lot.

I was a little disappointed in how the recent movies have represented Spider-Man as a teenager, when in the official Civil War arc in the comics presented him clearly as an adult. He even unmasked himself to the public in the comics, where he made it clear that he sided with Tony Stark. His character was ultimately redeemed by how accurately (?) they represented high school life in a way. It’s something the other two films could not have captured, so this gets major credit. Far better than TASM.

So yeah that’s it. Thanks for reading I guess.

blog.name: chucksnerdthoughts
blog.title: Chuck's Nerd Thoughts
blog.description: A place for all my nerdy thoughts.

title: Spider-Geddon #3
body:
Things are really kicking off! I am enjoying this so much! It was nice to see a little bit of recruitment. But then seeing the teams was really satisfying. Expect for when I realized that Jessica Drew was on Otto’s team. But she didn’t want to and was kind of tried onto it, so I can forgive it. It was real nice to see Silk again. I’ve missed her so much! And P//dr had a nice moment too. This whole thing just makes me so excited. I want to keep reading! 

Some moments that stood out. Spider-Ham’s argument about divided forces. His fears literally happened this issue. They almost had to kill themselves until Otto’s team showed. Otto’s mistrust of the Scarlet Spider. Its kind of more funny because he’s all about the team, whereas Osborn Spider-Man and Spiders-Man might actually be up to something evil. Though, if you think about it, their plan is just a more extreme version of Otto’s. “Acceptable losses.” That’s why killing people is a slippery slope! (That’s such a weird thing to say…) But I also loved when Otto pointed out that Takuya should just use his sword first because it is the most power and will end the conflict almost immediately. That was just perfect! (cough cough Pacific Rim cough cough) But yeah! Freaking loved this!! Cannot wait for more spidey goodness!!

-Chuck
